text: I wanted to talk a little bit about our need to have an ordering principle. Very important for us. Because what we are, by we I mean human beings, is extremely ordered pieces of the universe. There is a principle in physics, discovered in the 19th century, which is the principle of disorder. And of course its opposite, its algebraic negative, would therefore be the principle of order. And it's quite amazing that disorder turns out to be such an important part of understanding the physical world. Understanding chemical processes, for example, and in fact all physical processes. The laws of order and disorder are codified into the principles of thermodynamics. And order and disorder can actually be quantified. Numbers can be attached to them, they can be computed. How order and disorder change in a system can actually be expressed mathematically. So we measure length with feet or yards or meters. We measure time with seconds or hours or days or years. We measure mass with kilograms or plugs. A plug is 32 pounds used in the English system. We measure velocity in miles per hour or meters per second. What is the unit of disorder called, or what is the quantity that we measure when we measure the disorder of a system? It's entropy. E-N-T-R-O-P-Y. Entropy would be the opposite of entropy, which would be a measure of the order of a system. It turns out that what we call life has a lot of negative entropy. Life is a highly ordered pocket, a highly organized pocket, or a pocket of high organization within the universe. The universe as a whole has a tendency towards entropy. There's not a lot of order in a hydrogen cloud. But amazingly, as the universe as a whole becomes more and more disordered, that pushes pockets of order into existence inevitably. The discovery of this in the 19th century literally blew the minds of scientists. The disordering principle is actually the driving force that produces order in this universe. Amazingly. Doesn't make any sense at all. Just like, sounds like the way mystics talk. Doesn't make any sense at all. Einstein said of the principles of thermodynamics, if any discovery of science is likely to endure, it is this discovery. It's very deep. In any event, life represents a very significant pocket of negative entropy or high organization. And consciousness is an even greater degree of organization that arises upon life. So our consciousness needs an ordering principle. It's real important to our consciousness. It's of the nature of our consciousness to be ordered. And yet in this life we are constantly having to face the forces of entropy, of disorder. When disorder arises in the, and we are creatures of thought and feeling. Do you agree or not? Are you a creature of thought and feeling? I think you are. I know I am. So there's two kinds of disorder that we fear. One is the disorder in our conceptual process. Or I shouldn't say disorder, I should say lack of order. And when there's lack of order in our conceptual process, we call that confusion. And the other is lack of order in our feeling process. When there's lack of order in our feeling process, we call that suffering. So moment by moment we must fight. The mind is constantly fighting to figure stuff out. And the body is constantly fighting to get comfortable. Okay, that's our nature. But inevitably we can't figure stuff out always. And inevitably we can't get comfortable. So what we need is to have direct contact, direct contact, with an ordering principle that is so deep that it can never be disordered. That's what we really want. If we can have that, then we don't have to fear the vagaries and vicissitudes of conditions. Conditions of what? Conditions of the mind and body. All the order of your body can be taken away from you in the fraction of a second. Easy. All you have to do is, when you walk out of this room, flip on the stairs and break your spine. Easy. There'll be no more ordering principle in the body. All the ordering principle in the mind can be taken away from you. You get Alzheimer's. For me, if I was deprived of my.15 milligrams of thyroxine hormone that I have to take every day, within two weeks I have the IQ of a moron. It drops to about 40. All of my ability to think goes away. I've actually had it happen to me under controlled conditions in a hospital. Since the ordering can be taken away from us, it would be very nice to discover and to come into direct contact with an ordering principle that can never be taken away from us, no matter what. No matter what? Yeah, no matter what. No matter if you have Alzheimer's. No matter if your spine is broken. No matter if you don't have air to breathe. Well, that must be an awful deep ordering principle then. And it is. Why I mention this is that today in the guided meditation, I introduced a rather challenging object of meditation. The object of meditation being everything. Everything that was happening. One of the barriers to being able to meditate on everything, the moment by moment natural flow of awareness, is that it can produce a lot of chaos, a lot of confusion, confused feelings, disorientation in the mind, loss of sense of who you are and what's going on, etc. So when you start to broaden your object of meditation, if you narrow your object of meditation to something like the breath, you get a lot of ordering going on. But if you broaden your object of meditation to include everything, you have to come to grips with the fact that your ordinary ordering principles are going to fall apart. Because usually how do we order the world? Well, we establish a center, we establish boundaries, we have a sense of logic and continuity of meaning moment by moment. We have some sense of continuity in the feelings. But everything gets real broken and chopped up for a little while if we really surrender to the natural flow of awareness. So I bring up the topic of how to remain ordered when things get real chaotic. I bring that topic up tonight because it's relevant, it's germane to the aspect of broadening your meditation. So what is this ordering principle that can never be disordered? My teacher calls it the activity of expansion and contraction. No matter how confused the mind may become, sometimes it's more confused, sometimes it's less confused. The confusion spreads, the confusion collapses. There's an order there. You might say, well, that order doesn't do me any good. But it does. If you ride on it, if you become it, you'll find that it has all the order you possibly need. Likewise, the body gets full of all sorts of chaotic feelings, lots of different flavors, lots of different directions in space, very confusing, disorienting. But each one wells up and passes away, wells up and passes away, spreads and collapses. That rhythm is an ordering principle. So however disordered the content of a person's experience may be, the contour is always perfectly ordered. And if we can surf the contour, then we will find meaning and satisfaction in each moment. Our usual concept of meaning is, we understand this, we understand that. Our usual concept of satisfaction is, this feels good, that feels good. But there's a deeper meaning in life, and there's a deeper satisfaction in life that can never be taken from us. When we encounter the deeper meaning of the mind, all thoughts mean exactly the same thing. What do they mean? They mean a meaning that we cannot put into words, a meaning that is a meaning, but we can't conceive of it or talk about it. Because the human mind and the human mouth can only talk about this or that meaning, or only conceive of this or that meaning. The meaning that comes about when we let go of this or that meaning, the meaning of the movement of consciousness is all meaning. All meanings in the universe are contained within that meaning. So from a human perspective, that's no meaning. But from another perspective, it's the ultimate meaning, the sum of all meaning. So it's both no meaning and all meanings at the same time. So when we relate to the thinking mind in terms of its movement, rather than in terms of its specific meaning, when we relate to the thinking mind in terms of its billowing contour, rather than its specific content, we have this experience of all meaning, but the human mind says that it's no meaning. But deep down we know it's all meaning. And therefore, we are absolutely ordered, no matter how confused it may seem. We're bathed in infinite meaning. Likewise, the body gets filled with all sorts of chaotic feelings. They go here, they go here, there, they go to the right, they go to the left. It's this flavor, it's that flavor. But what unifies it is they well up, they subside, they expand, they contract. And when we ride the contour of feeling, then all feelings feel the same. What's the feeling? It's the feeling of purification, the feeling of release, the feeling of satisfaction independent of conditioning, of freedom independent of circumstances. Everything feels the same. Pleasure, pain, emotion, physical, all feels the same. Via Unitiva in Latin, the unitive way, the experience of oneness. Most spiritual traditions talk about the one. Sarvam ekam in Sanskrit, it's all one. Most of the Greek philosophers talked about tohen, it means the one. The unity of things. Well, it's a nice idea and it may give us some warm fuzzies at the level of feeling to conceive of that there's really one, we're all united, we're all relative. But to go beyond the warm fuzzy stage and the intellectual speculation stage and to directly experience the one, this is our real challenge. Well, there's lots of ways to go about it. One way to go about it is to work through duality or separateness. There are three deep dualities that we human beings are subject to. It's hard to unify. Maybe it's almost impossible to unify. But it's at least doable to work through duality, to break down separation is doable. And of course, when we break down separation, we achieve oneness automatically. I like to conceive of the task of experiencing oneness, directly experiencing oneness, not so much as the task of experiencing oneness, but as the task of seeing through separation, which to me is a much more doable task. So what are the fundamental separations? What are the wounds that are gouged into the one body of the spirit? Well, certainly there is a separation between thought and feeling in most people. Most people also do not realize that the separation between thought and feeling is exactly equivalent to the separation between mind and body, using mind here in the sense of thinking mind. Some people use mind in other senses. People talk about mind-body integration. They talk about thought and feeling integration, head and heart integration. Good. Nice idea. In order for two things that appear to be separate to be experienced as not separate, we must pay attention to that which they have in common, that which cuts across their boundaries constantly, so that the boundary then will become invisible. Well, what does the mind have in common with the body? What does thought have in common with feeling? It's a contraction. There's more, there's less. It spreads here, puffs out there, it pulls in there. The easiest is the body. Pay attention to it. It becomes amoeba-like at some point, expanding, contracting, at many frequencies, in many directions, at many amplitudes simultaneously. Pay attention to the mind, the thinking mind long enough, you discover it's exactly the same. It's a space of vibration, circulation, converging and diverging, flux lines. And when you experience the body that way, and then you also experience the mind that way, those flux lines cut across the boundary over and over and over again, until there is no boundary. It becomes a single mind-body doing. This is called to be an integrated person at a psychological level. But it's also called a complete experience of your true self at a spiritual level. This is one way. I wouldn't for a moment say it's the only way. But this is one way to tangibly heal the separation between mind and body. That's an old separation, but it's not as old as some. How old is that separation? In the realm of millennia, a few thousand years, I would guess, I would imagine it's no more than since the Neolithic revolution that the separation became real dramatic with the hypertrophy of the thinking mind that comes with literate civilizations. Of course, our job is hardly to negate the glorious achievements of civilization. Our job is very much what Hegel said, to unite both worlds, to have the best of both worlds. Thesis, antithesis, synthesis. Our distant ancestors, the thesis, lived probably much more in a state of oneness of mind and body. Then the antithesis, civilization, develops. So what's the synthesis? Meditation. Best of both worlds. Oneness of mind and body without having to let go of all of the doing and knowing that constitutes civilization. Okay, be that as it may. An older separation is the separation of inside and outside. That's pretty old. How far back does it go? To the first flatworms that developed an eye, EYE. A little spot of pigment that gave them a sense that there was an outside world. I don't know, but it's pretty old. Obviously, the cleft deepens as the species develop more and more complexity through evolution. Separation of inside and outside. But what's the outside? How do you know there's an outside world? You see it? You hear it? Mostly that's how you know there's an outside world. Yeah, you touch it too. And you think about it, and you smell it, and you taste it. All the senses produce the sense of outside world. But primarily our concept of there is outside comes about through the seeing and the hearing. And somewhat through, as I say, there's of course the touching aspect and the thinking aspect. But when you begin to have a complete experience of the visual field as a space of light, and you begin to have the complete experience of the hearing process as a space of sound, the subtle congealing in the luminous sense and in the acoustic sense start to break up. It's just like the body, exactly like the body sensation. It's the same process. That's why my personal style, I like to start people out with the body sensations, because that's usually the easiest space to experience expansion and contraction. A little more challenging, not a little more challenging, a lot more challenging is the thinking. But the thinking is a space. There's the two or three dimensional screen of the imaging. There is the volume of internal hearing that constitutes the dialogue. That's a space. The subtle processing very much occupies, the subtle mental processing creates a volume of space. That space can be penetrated and it goes through the same process that the body space goes through. It turns into an amoeba. I've talked about that. Well, the same is true for the luminous space. But there the congealings, the blockages, the tensions are incomparably more subtle. The blockages in the body are not that subtle. As soon as there's any congealing in the body, you've got suffering. But the visual field can congeal like crazy, precipitating the sense of material objects all the time. It doesn't cause very much suffering, so there's not very much motivation to break up the friction in the flow of vision. But when it starts to break up, you realize there is subtle suffering in that friction. As long as there's a solid material world outside of you, there's suffering. Not like your eye is suffering, UIE. Because it's being impinged upon. Vision, there's a right side, there's a left side, there's a top side, there's a bottom side, there's a front side, there's a back side. Oh, it's a big space, all right. It's bigger than your body, usually. Although your body can get pretty big sometimes, as you probably noticed. But you can still surround that space. You can still free float in that space of light. You can sleep through that space of light. You can evenly cover that space of light. In short, you can apply the entire panoply of body awareness techniques to the space of light. And that's to begin to have a complete experience of the seeing process. Hearing. Well, you may get a noticeable sound over here, a noticeable sound over there. But if you pay attention to just what's happening on the right side of your hearing, sometimes there's noticeable sounds there. Sometimes there's sort of a background presence. Sometimes there's silence. But that's all hearing. You hear the absence of sound. That's still the hearing process. That's a perception. You know that when you go from a noisy street into a quiet room. For just a moment, you actually hear the silence. And then you acclimate to it. But when you meditate, you never acclimate to anything. Every moment is completely fresh, as though you had never experienced the previous moment. I can claim that, but actually this is one claim I can back up with object of research. If you read the book, I think it's called Zen and Psychotherapy, I could be wrong on the title. But it's a paperback by two Japanese researchers, Hirai and Kasamatsu. H-I-R-A-I, Hirai and Kasamatsu, K-A-S-A-M-A-T-S-U. They attached electrodes to a test group and to a group of experienced Zen meditators and monitored the brainwave as these groups were exposed to the same stimuli. And they discovered something that was not in any of the textbooks. An aspect of human physiology that no one had ever suspected could happen. There's a distinctive brainwave pattern that arises whenever a new stimulus impinges on the environment. And then within a few seconds, that distinctive pattern of brainwaves goes away. It's called an orienting response. And it can be monitored easily with brainwave equipment. So what they did is, as one group of people who were not meditators were just sitting still, and another group of people who were Zen meditators were sitting still, they introduced a periodic click into the environment and watched the brainwave. Well, the non-meditator group showed what all the textbooks on human physiology show. There's an orienting response for the first few clicks, and then it goes away. The click isn't new anymore. But the Zen meditators always had an orienting response, no matter how many times they introduced the click. Objective demonstration of the subjective claim of meditation, that this moment is completely fresh and that you don't acclimate, you don't accommodate. That's, I would call, a rather impressive piece of research. You go into a room, you hear the silence, and then you don't hear it anymore, you acclimate to it. The meditator, if there's nothing happening in the acoustic field on the right, hears the silence on the right moment by moment, if they are meditating in the acoustic field. So, on the right there's either silence or there's what's called background presence. You know what that means? Like, when they shoot a scene in a movie, they'll sometimes just record the empty set, and then they need to use that at other times. That's correct, isn't it? I'm not sure what they use it for, but... What's that called? Room tone. Okay, room tone. Very good. Right, the sound of the silent room. Room tone, I'm going to remember that. That room tone is very important, or that space tone, whatever, is very important in meditating in the acoustic field. Because you want to get the sense of spatiality. Spatiality always means right, left, front, back, top, bottom. We're in three-dimensional Euclidean space here. Of course, and all the intermediate directions. Like the American Indians say, the six directions. On the right there's either something obvious happening, or you're aware of the tone, or you're aware of silence. But likewise in all the other directions at the same time. That's to cover the acoustic field with awareness. So what happens when you cover the acoustic field with awareness? Then the field of sound goes through the same process that your body went through. Expands here, contracts there. It becomes undulatory, you start to get massaged in the hearing sense. You start to get meditated by the ambient sound. So then what happens when your hearing sense and your visual sense become expanding and contracting fields of energy? And then your feeling sense and your thinking sense also do so. So then the borders between inside and outside break down. For real. However, this is why I brought up the ordering principle. It's very hard to do this, because we have a habit of thinking that our order is dependent on separating inside and outside. It's a very deep habit. How deep? Cellular, I would say. And I use the word cellular with great caution. A lot of people say cellular. They use that word in an extremely careless way. Like the blockage is at a cellular level. Or, you know, the, I don't know, this is reaching a cellular level. Usually that involves what I would consider to be wild, unsubstantiated claims. What reaches a cellular level. But I would say that the separation of inside and outside is cellular. Because that's what the cell is all about. Right? Those of you that have studied the life sciences, studied cytology, studied biochemistry, that's exactly what the cell is all about. It's about a bilipid layer. Okay? So it's amazing how life started. Okay? You know what it all goes back to? At the absolute fundamental level of our chemistry. How the cells originally formed. It all goes back to this seemingly incredibly trivial fact that oil and water don't mix. You've noticed that, right? Basically there's two kinds of substances. Polar substances and nonpolar substances. And water is highly polar. And oily things, lipids, are highly nonpolar. What happens is, if you get a bilipid layer, a layer that has lipids, which means oily stuff, on both sides, and the oil molecules are held together, I think they're held together by proteins and sugars, aren't they? And the oily parts, the hydrocarbon chains, are sticking out on both sides. Now you can separate two volumes of water, salt water. You can have a salt concentration inside that bilipid layer that is different from the salt concentration outside. And that ability, because it started in the ocean with salt, that ability to surround a little piece of the salt water and sequester it off, which is apparently what some oil slick did, or maybe a thousand oil slicks did, I don't know. It's sort of humbling to think that we started out as an oil slick. Okay? But it's also wondrous, isn't it? Somehow the thing became a closed sphere. So now you could separate the inside water from the outside water, and then stuff started to transport back and forth, and pretty soon you had negative entropy building up inside that cell, turning into organelles, and the membrane was semi-permeable, you could have ion transport in and out. That's basically what a cell does. It transports sodium ions back and forth, and it builds up an osmotic pressure gradient, and then it can make use of that osmotic pressure any time it wants to convert it into different kinds of energy to do the activities of the cell. It's just amazing. Anyway, clearly the separation of inside and outside is at a cellular level. That's how life started, a bilipid layer that could separate two kinds of salt water. So we're in the habit, at a very deep level, to associate our sense of order with a sense of separation of inside and outside, and yet we desperately need to experience the oneness of inside and outside. We'll never be happy, we'll never be free, we'll never be fulfilled, we'll never be safe, as long as there's outside and inside fundamentally separate for us. So if we ground ourselves in expansion and contraction, in impermanence, then all the senses become expansion and contraction, and the aspects of sense that produces outside and the aspects of sense that produces inside, they merge, and we have a direct experience of a flow across those boundaries. What is the flux? What is the flow? It's just the flow of expansion and contraction, of more and less. That then unifies inside and outside. But the deepest of all separation is the separation between our spiritual source and our self, including, in the word self, one's whole surrounding scene. So the self and the scene, creation, seem separate from the creator. So how to bridge that gap? Well, it turns out that, at least according to the way I was taught, and according to the way I experience it, may be different for other people, may be different for you. I can only share what I've been taught, what I've experienced. That source is a kind of nothing, and therefore, being nothing, of course, it contains all positive and negative at once, and therefore, is capable of polarizing into positive and negative. And that is to say, polarizing into expansive and contractive, affirmative and denying, allowing and limiting aspects. And as soon as it polarizes, it will churn, it cannot help but churn into existence, time, space, self and world. So the source itself expands and contracts. And if we are willing to yield long enough to these forces, they will massage us so that we become elastic enough so that we can really yield. And then at some point when the forces reunite back into zero, we experience the products of the source, creation, self and surrounding scene. We experience the products of the source being carried back to the source. And then what? And then there's true peace. There's true completeness. There's true oneness. For how long? Well, by an external clock, could be a fraction of a second. It could be many hours or days, depending on the degree of insight and purification of the meditator. That's by an external clock. But just like there are no bathrooms or restaurants in heaven, most assuredly, there are no clocks or watches. But by an external clock, after a fraction of a second or much longer, again, there's a repolarization and the stillness breaks up into energy. The original recording ended abruptly at this point.
